This may be an old video.... but what the heck:
It seems as though the "Grandfather Paradox" is easily avoided: whatever changes are done during the time travel trip, the illusion that it didn't happen must be maintained. Only AFTER origin date of the timetravler's departure can the changes be reveled. It's only a paradox if the time traveler's past was ACTUALLY changed. If you "recreate" the past as it is remembered... how do you know that it wasn't always that way? As long as the timetravler's BELIEF of the situation is unchanged at the time of departure, then there is no paradox.

For example.... loved one dies. You know you can save them. Go back in time. Save them. Fake their death in the same way that the memory is remembered. Bring them back to the original time. Cause and effect are intact and the person is saved.

Or you kill your grandfather. Take his place and live the rest of his life for him.

To sum this up one could not send the winning lottery numbers back in time if the numbers are actually randomly generated. This is because the more time allowed between events the larger influence of change.
This being said time travelers would never risk showing up in person because if it were possible we would simply un-create our selves and time would simply move forward no paradox. Or to be more precise we would have to blow up the universe as we know it to go back into the past which would simply change the likely hood of trying to blow up the universe to pointlessly go back into time. Traveling forward in time at a faster rate than you are used to is a simple matter of traveling at, or near, the speed of light.  As you approach the speed of light, time will slow down for you, meaning it will speed up for the rest of us.  If you travel away from the earth for 10 light years, at a speed that is close to the speed of light, then it would seem to you that you hadn't been traveling for very long at all.  If  you turn around and travel back, again at a speed that approaches the speed of light, then you would find upon returning that everyone other than you had aged 20 years during what seemed like a short amount of time for you.

Going back in time is also possible, but it involves warping time with an intense amount of mass.  We're talking about the mass of multiple suns condensed into the size of a golf-ball.  The density would be so intense, that light would be unable to escape the pull of gravity near it.  If you were able to approach this variation in time density at or near the speed of light, without being drawn in, and/or obliterated by the incredible gravity near the source of the warp, then theoretically, time could reverse for you only.  

If someone could observe you during this voyage, which is impossible since light can't escape the anomaly, it would appear to them that you were actually traveling faster than the speed of light.

Going backwards is much more theoretical than going forward, but it's easy to imagine if you can wrap your brain around the idea that time is just another dimension.  It is just as real and variable as space, temperature or gravity, even though with time you normally only experience the slow, steady drag forward during your lifetime.  Gravity was thought to be constant for a long time, but we know today that a person on the moon can jump a lot higher than a person on the earth and everyone experiences temperature fluctuations on a regular basis.

Light is mostly energy, but also has some mass, and all mass is made up of energy.  This exercise in relativity is the kind of thing that Einstein warmed up with.

Time travel would be impossible for many reasons, but I will share a few here.
First, the law of preservation of matter, and its counterpart, the law of preservation of energy. Since destruction's definition is to take out of existence, wouldn't simply leaving a place in a timeline be destruction of your matter? Also, wouldn't entering another moment be creation of matter?
Second, if you could get past the first reason, you would need a void of all matter. Entering a point in space is normally harmless, but if there is already matter of any kind there, the result could cause anything from instant vaporization to a possible nuclear reaction, since matter cannot occupy the same space as other matter. Imagine if you landed in someone when you arrived?
Third, if the traveler SOMEHOW got a void, and made it safely, they wouldn't be able to do anything, because of the reasons stated in the video.

Have fun with your space travel shenanigans while defying laws of nature and getting vaporized. I'm sad about it too.

That doesn't prove time travel is possible, it proves that it can flow forward at different rates. "Time" is a subjective measure of the passage of events. Events can pass at different rates, but that doesn't mean you can travel up and down some imaginary "stream" of time. Want proof? Discover this magical thing called "Logic." 1. If time travel were possible, we'd already see time travelers on a regular basis. 2. Time travel creates "paradoxes", which are really just logical failures that betray the impossibility of the scenario you are proposing, not puzzles to be solved. The "grandfather clause" or any other scenario, like trying to save Kennedy, doesn't create some ridiculous "butterfly effect", it's just a really tricky way of displaying the impossibility of the "time travel" scenario. Once you understand "time" as our subjective perception of the constant passage of events, you can immediately understand how ridiculous it is to try and "travel" to a set of events that no longer exists, because it was a fleeting snapshot in a passage of events that happened once and is now gone. You obviously can't also travel forward in time... because those events haven't happened yet. The only form of "time travel" that could be possible is time viewing... which would only be possible through an infinite understanding of causal relationships. You could view, in your infinite mind, everything that had ever happened and ever will happen by examining the current state of events. This doesn't mean you could "go" to that place.

My theory how time travel could work (it's unfinished and was made for sci-fi settings):
Let's take the setting of Grandfather Paradox: you go to the past and kill your grandfather. During the time travel itself, time enters a superposition: in one state you arrive in the past, in other you don't, but both are true at the same time. As it is possible to observe ("be in") only one time state at the time, you could say time splits in two and you arrive in one of them and any action doesn't influence another one in any way. Thus, you can go to past and kill your grandfather, but that will only make him a Schrödinger’s cat that's both dead and alive, thus you won't cease to exist. Simple.

I see what you mean, but I think it's more reasonable to apply Occam's razor here. generallemur stated that the past can't be changed since it had already happened. By traveling back in time, you have already changed the past even if you don't do anything. Assuming that the world will sort itself out by various means in order to keep the timeline going in such a way that you will travel back in time so that the loop is completed sounds very elaborate, don't you agree?

No it wouldn't. It isn't impossible to show that a given postulate isn't true, but they also aren't something you can really prove either. For example, Einstein's postulate about the speed of light could be disproven by showing that something can move faster than the speed of light. While this would break our "known" laws of physics, it wouldn't break THE laws of physics since the laws that truly govern physics will exist regardless of our knowledge of them.

That's true, but what blarghonk8 seems to imply would break the laws of physics and introduce some rather complex ones. Imagine if it was impossible for you to kill someone? Bullets stopping mid air, skin impenetrable by knives, or perhaps your mind will be altered by some force so that you don't want to kill him anymore. This is beyond the rules of physics :) Anyway, if you have already traveled back in time, your very presence would be a change thus introducing the paradox.
The universe would make it possible. You don't necessarily have to be sentient to make those sort of rules. The laws of physics are rules but clearly exist.

Well, yes and no. You are correct that it would imply a set of rules that govern time travel, but so does the solution to the paradox. Any sort of science (or math, or anything) really depends upon assumed rules or postulates that must be taken on faith that they are true. The speed of light being the same for all reference frames for example, or how Euclidean geometry falls apart if you are on a spherical surface rather than a flat one. Any theory implies a governing set of assumed rules.
